race.name: Gravel Locos
race.tagline: The free race with legendary Texas hospitality. Where gravel meets community.

vitals.registration: Free but donations welcome. Opens fall prior.
vitals.aid_stations: Community-run aid stations with Texas hospitality

climate.description: February in Texas brings variable conditions—could be 35°F or 70°F

terrain.primary: Texas Hill Country gravel and ranch roads
terrain.surface: Variable Texas gravel—hard-packed to loose, with cattle guard crossings

history.origin_story: Created as a free, community-driven gravel event showcasing Texas Hill Country. Bobby Wintle's vision of grassroots hospitality applied to Texas—because gravel racing should be accessible.
notable_moments: Remains free in an era of $200+ entries
Hico embraces the event as community festival
history.reputation: The anti-corporate gravel race. Where hospitality matters more than prize purses.

course_description.character: Classic Texas gravel—rolling, exposed, beautiful in a rugged Hill Country way.

suffering_zones.label: Deep Country
suffering_zones.desc: Ranch country isolation. Just you and the road.

suffering_zones.label: Home Stretch
suffering_zones.desc: Hico in sight but legs are tired. BBQ motivation.

course_description.signature_challenge: The combination of distance, February conditions, and early-season fitness. This is often a season opener—meaning legs aren't ready.

prestige.explanation: Not a bucket-list name-drop race, but deeply respected for what it represents. Bobby Wintle's involvement gives it credibility in the gravel world.

length.explanation: 115 miles is serious distance, especially early in the season. The February timing means many riders are undertrained.

technicality.explanation: Texas gravel isn't technical. Cattle guards require attention. Otherwise it's about fitness, not handling.

elevation.explanation: 6,500 feet across 115 miles is steady rolling. Not punishing, but constant. Hill Country terrain never truly flattens.

climate.explanation: February is wildcard season. Could be shorts weather or full winter kit. Pack layers and hope.

altitude.explanation: Texas Hill Country sits at modest elevation. Altitude is irrelevant.

adventure.explanation: Hico and the Hill Country have genuine Texas charm. Ranch country, small-town vibes, and the legendary post-race experience.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Locos represents everything good about grassroots gravel: free entry, community spirit, legendary hospitality, and a genuinely fun day on the bike. In an era of $250 entries and lottery stress, this is refreshing.
strengths: Free: You literally can't beat the price.
Community: Hico embraces the event. Volunteers are amazing.
Bobby Wintle: The same spirit that made Unbound special, applied to Texas.
weaknesses: February timing: Season opener fitness means many riders suffer.
Limited infrastructure: Free race means modest production value.
Hico is small: Lodging requires planning or road trip approach.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want to experience what gravel racing should feel like—welcoming, fun, community-driven—Gravel Locos delivers. The price is right and the vibe is unmatched.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: Free doesn't mean easy. February fitness levels combined with Texas wind and 115 miles creates real suffering. Many riders use this as a 'training race' and end up humbled.
consequences: February fitness is often weak. Prepare accordingly.
Hico has limited lodging. Book early or plan day-of arrival.
Don't skip the post-race BBQ. It's the whole point.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This is a community celebration with bikes. Race if you want, but come for the experience. The clock matters less than the vibes.

final_verdict.one_liner: Free gravel racing with Texas hospitality—where community comes first and everyone's welcome.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want grassroots gravel, early-season miles, and legendary hospitality. Yes if corporate racing feels soulless. Not if you need Instagram prestige.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want Texas gravel later in year: various Hill Country events. If you want similar grassroots vibes: look for community-organized races near you.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Hico is tiny. Book immediately or stay in Stephenville (20 min) or Waco (45 min).
logistics.food: Hico has basics. Post-race BBQ is legendary and provided.
logistics.packet_pickup: Morning of race or day before. Simple process.
